Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Situation2: They hear that a community member is feeling down and occasionally check in with a kind word.
Story: I stood in the workshop, the hum of the machines louder than usual, a sure sign that something was wrong. The temperature gauges blinked red—these machines had missed their last service, and now they were running dangerously hot. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “We can’t afford downtime. Keep them running smoothly.” I rolled up my sleeves, ready to get to work, when my phone buzzed. It was a message from Mary, a member of my congregation. “Heard you’re busy, but if you have a moment, could you check in on Tom? He’s been feeling really low lately.” As a pastor, I knew how much a simple call or a kind word could mean. But as a repairer, I also knew that every minute I delayed could mean a costly breakdown. My hands hovered over my tools, my heart pulled in two directions—toward the machines that needed me, and the people who needed me even more.
